sentences.llm_translation: There, since it is written: “and the land shall be subdued before HaShem, and afterward you shall return” — it implies from here onward. But here, if it עולה upon your mind as they are written, “and he passed” after tum’ah and setirah — kinui, for what do I need?

sentences.text: תָּנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: אֵין אָדָם מְקַנֵּא לְאִשְׁתּוֹ אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן נִכְנְסָה בּוֹ רוּחַ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְעָבַר עָלָיו רוּחַ קִנְאָה וְקִנֵּא אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ״. מַאי רוּחַ?
sentences.human_translation: The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: A man issues a warning to his wife only if a spirit entered him, as it is stated: “And the spirit of jealousy came upon him, and he warned his wife” what spirit
sentences.llm_translation: Tana deVei Rabbi Yishma’el: A man does not become jealous of his wife unless a spirit entered into him, as it is said: “and a spirit of jealousy passed over him, and he became jealous of his wife.” What is “spirit”?

sentences.text: רַבָּנַן אָמְרִי: רוּחַ טוּמְאָה. רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: רוּחַ טׇהֳרָה.
sentences.human_translation: The Rabbis say: A spirit of impurity, Rav Ashi says: A spirit of purity,
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbannan amri: a spirit of impurity. Rav Ashi amar: a spirit of purity.

sentences.text: וּמִסְתַּבְּרָא כְּמַאן דְּאָמַר רוּחַ טׇהֳרָה. דְּתַנְיָא: ״וְקִנֵּא אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ״ — רְשׁוּת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: חוֹבָה. אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא רוּחַ טׇהֳרָה — שַׁפִּיר, אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ רוּחַ טוּמְאָה, רְשׁוּת וְחוֹבָה לְעַיּוֹלֵי לְאִינִישׁ רוּחַ טוּמְאָה בְּנַפְשֵׁיהּ?
sentences.human_translation: And stands to reason like the one who says a spirit of purity, as it is taught “And he warned his wife,” optional, the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: mandatory, Granted, if you say a spirit of purity, well, But if you say a spirit of impurity, optional or mandatory for a person to introduce a spirit of impurity into himself?
sentences.llm_translation: And it is reasonable according to the one who says: ru’aḥ ṭoharah. For it is taught: “And he shall warn his wife” — optional, the words of Rabbi Yishma’el. Rabbi Akiva says: obligation. If you say well, ru’aḥ ṭoharah — fine; but if you say ru’aḥ tum’ah, optional and obligation for a man to bring in ru’aḥ tum’ah into himself?

sentences.text: גּוּפָא: ״וְקִנֵּא אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ״ — רְשׁוּת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: חוֹבָה. ״לָהּ יִטַּמָּא״ — רְשׁוּת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: חוֹבָה.
sentences.human_translation: the itself. “And he warned his wife,” optional; the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. And Rabbi Akiva says: mandatory. “For her may he become impure” optional; the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. And Rabbi Akiva says: mandatory
sentences.llm_translation: Gufa: “And he shall warn his wife” — permission, the words of Rabbi Yishma’el. And Rabbi Akiva says: obligation. “For her he shall become impure” — permission, the words of Rabbi Yishma’el. And Rabbi Akiva says: obligation.

sentences.text: ״לְעֹלָם בָּהֶם תַּעֲבֹדוּ״ — רְשׁוּת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: חוֹבָה.
sentences.human_translation: “Of them may you take your bondmen forever” optional, this is the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: mandatory,
sentences.llm_translation: “‘Le-olam bahem ta’avodu’ — permission, the words of Rabbi Yishma’el. Rabbi Akiva says: obligation.”

sentences.text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב פָּפָּא לְאַבָּיֵי, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ רַב מְשַׁרְשְׁיָא לְרָבָא: לֵימָא רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא בְּכׇל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ הָכִי פְּלִיגִי, דְּמָר אָמַר רְשׁוּת וּמָר אָמַר חוֹבָה? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הָכָא בִּקְרָאֵי פְּלִיגִי.
sentences.human_translation: Rav Pappa said to Abaye, and some say Rav Mesharshiyya to Rava: Shall we say Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva disagree this with regard to the entire Torah? that master, says optional, and master, says mandatory. said to Here, they disagree with regard to verses,
sentences.llm_translation: אָמַר לֵיהּ Rav Pappa to Abaye, and they say it Rav Mesharshiya to Rava: Let us say Rabbi Yishma’el and Rabbi Akiva in the entire Torah, all of it, thus they disagree, that the Master says: optional, and the Master says: obligation? He said to him: Here, in verses, they disagree.

sentences.text: ״וְקִנֵּא אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ״ — רְשׁוּת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: חוֹבָה.
sentences.human_translation: “And he warned his wife,” optional; the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: mandatory.
sentences.llm_translation: “‘And he warned his wife’ — optional, the words of Rabbi Yishmaʿel. Rabbi ʿAkiva says: obligation.”

sentences.text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל — סָבַר לַהּ כִּי הַאי תַּנָּא, דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב אוֹמֵר: כְּלַפֵּי שֶׁאָמְרָה תּוֹרָה ״לֹא תִשְׂנָא אֶת אָחִיךָ בִּלְבָבֶךָ״, יָכוֹל כְּגוֹן זוֹ? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְעָבַר עָלָיו רוּחַ קִנְאָה וְקִנֵּא אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ״.
sentences.human_translation: What is the reason of Rabbi Yishmael? holds in accordance with this tanna , as it is taught Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: With regard to which the Torah said: “You shall not hate your brother in your heart” might such as this the verse states: “And the spirit of jealousy came upon him, and he warned his wife”
sentences.llm_translation: What is the reason of Rabbi Yishma’el? — He holds like that tanna, as it is taught: Rabbi Eli’ezer ben Ya‘akov says: With regard to that which the Torah said, “You shall not hate your brother in your heart,” might one think like this? The verse teaches to say: “And a spirit of jealousy passed over him, and he was jealous of his wife.”

sentences.text: וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: קִינּוּי אַחֲרִינָא כְּתִיב.
sentences.human_translation: And Rabbi Akiva is another warning written
sentences.llm_translation: And Rabbi ʿAqiva: another qinui is written.

sentences.text: וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל? אַיְּידֵי דְּבָעֵי לְמִיכְתַּב ״וְהִיא נִטְמָאָה״ ״וְהִיא לֹא נִטְמָאָה״ — כְּתִיב נָמֵי ״וְקִנֵּא אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ״.
sentences.human_translation: And Rabbi Yishmael Since it needed to write “And she be defiled,” “And she be not defiled,” it is also written: “And he warned his wife,”
sentences.llm_translation: And Rabbi Yishmaʿel? Since that he needed to write “and she became defiled,” “and she did not become defiled” — it is written also “and he warned his wife.”

sentences.text: לְכִדְתָנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. דְּתָנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: כָּל פָּרָשָׁה שֶׁנֶּאֶמְרָה וְנִישְׁנֵית — לֹא נִישְׁנֵית אֶלָּא בִּשְׁבִיל דָּבָר שֶׁנִּתְחַדֵּשׁ בָּהּ.
sentences.human_translation: as taught by the school of Rabbi Yishmael, as the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Every passage that was stated and repeated was repeated only for the novel element introduced therein.
sentences.llm_translation: According to the tanna of the house of Rabbi Yishma’el. For the house of Rabbi Yishma’el taught: Any parashah that was said and repeated — it was not repeated except on account of a matter that was renewed in it.

sentences.text: ״לָהּ יִטַּמָּא״ — רְשׁוּת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: חוֹבָה.
sentences.human_translation: for her may he become impure” optional; the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: mandatory
sentences.llm_translation: “‘For her he shall become impure’ — optional, the words of Rabbi Yishmaʿel. Rabbi ʿAqiva says: an obligation.”

sentences.text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל — אַיְּידֵי דִּכְתִיב: ״אֱמֹר אֶל הַכֹּהֲנִים בְּנֵי אַהֲרֹן וְאָמַרְתָּ אֲלֵיהֶם לְנֶפֶשׁ לֹא יִטַּמָּא בְּעַמָּיו״, אִיצְטְרִיכָא לְמִיכְתַּב ״לָהּ יִטַּמָּא״.
sentences.human_translation: What is the reason of Rabbi Yishmael? Since it is written: “Speak to the priests, the sons of Aaron, and say to them: There shall none become impure for the dead among his people” was necessary to be written: “For her may he become impure,”
sentences.llm_translation: What is the reason of Rabbi Yishmaʿel? — Since it is written: “Speak to the kohanim, the sons of Aharon, and say to them: for a soul he shall not become impure among his peoples,” it was necessary to write: “for her he shall become impure.”

sentences.text: וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא מִ״כִּי אִם לִשְׁאֵרוֹ״ נָפְקָא, ״לָהּ יִטַּמָּא״ לְמָה לִי — לְחוֹבָה.
sentences.human_translation: And Rabbi Akiva derives from “Except for his kin, why do I “For her may he become impure”? To mandatory.
sentences.llm_translation: And Rabbi Akiva—from “except for his kin” it emerges; “for her he shall become impure,” why do I need it?—for obligation.

sentences.text: וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: לָהּ מִיטַּמֵּא, וְאֵין מִיטַּמֵּא לְאֵיבָרֶיהָ.
sentences.human_translation: And Rabbi Yishmael he may become impure for her, but he may not become impure to her limbs.
sentences.llm_translation: And Rabbi Yishmaʿel: to her he becomes impure, and he does not become impure to her limbs.

text: וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא — אִם כֵּן, לִיכְתּוֹב רַחֲמָנָא ״לָהּ״ וְלִישְׁתּוֹק, ״יִטַּמָּא״ לְמָה לִי? שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.

וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, אַיְּידֵי דִּכְתַב ״לָהּ״, כְּתַב נָמֵי ״יִטַּמָּא״. לְכִדְתָנֵי דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. דְּתָנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: כָּל פָּרָשָׁה שֶׁנֶּאֶמְרָה וְנִישְׁנֵית, לֹא נִישְׁנֵית אֶלָּא בִּשְׁבִיל דָּבָר שֶׁנִּתְחַדֵּשׁ בָּהּ.
״לְעֹלָם בָּהֶם תַּעֲבֹדוּ״ — רְשׁוּת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר: חוֹבָה.

מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל — אַיְּידֵי דִּכְתִיב ״לֹא תְחַיֶּה כׇּל נְשָׁמָה״, אִיצְטְרִיךְ נָמֵי לְמִיכְתַּב ״לְעֹלָם בָּהֶם תַּעֲבֹדוּ״, לְמִישְׁרֵי אֶחָד מִכׇּל הָאוּמּוֹת שֶׁבָּא עַל הַכְּנַעֲנִית וְהוֹלִיד מִמֶּנָּה בֵּן, שֶׁאַתָּה רַשַּׁאי לִקְנוֹתוֹ.

דְּתַנְיָא: מִנַּיִן לְאֶחָד מִן הָאוּמּוֹת שֶׁבָּא עַל הַכְּנַעֲנִית וְהוֹלִיד מִמֶּנָּה בֵּן, שֶׁאַתָּה רַשַּׁאי לִקְנוֹתוֹ בְּעֶבֶד, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְגַם מִבְּנֵי הַתּוֹשָׁבִים הַגָּרִים עִמָּכֶם מֵהֶם תִּקְנוּ״.

יָכוֹל אַף הַכְּנַעֲנִי שֶׁבָּא עַל אַחַת מִן הָאוּמּוֹת וְהוֹלִיד מִמֶּנָּה בֵּן, שֶׁאַתָּה רַשַּׁאי לִקְנוֹתוֹ בְּעֶבֶד, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אֲשֶׁר הוֹלִידוּ בְּאַרְצְכֶם״, מִן הַנּוֹלָדִים בְּאַרְצְכֶם, וְלֹא מִן הַגָּרִים בְּאַרְצְכֶם.
וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא מִ״מֵּהֶם תִּקְנוּ״ נָפְקָא, ״לְעֹלָם בָּהֶם תַּעֲבֹדוּ״ לְמָה לִי — לְחוֹבָה.
וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: ״בָּהֶם״ — וְלֹא בְּאַחֵיכֶם.
וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא: בְּאַחֵיכֶם — מִסֵּיפָא דִּקְרָא נָפְקָא: ״וּבְאַחֵיכֶם בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל אִישׁ בְּאָחִיו לֹא תִרְדֶּה בוֹ בְּפָרֶךְ״.

וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: אַיְּידֵי דִּכְתִיב ״וּבְאַחֵיכֶם״, כְּתִיב נָמֵי ״בָּהֶם״. לְכִדְתָנֵי דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. דְּתָנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: כָּל פָּרָשָׁה שֶׁנֶּאֶמְרָה וְנִישְׁנֵית, לֹא נִישְׁנֵית אֶלָּא בִּשְׁבִיל דָּבָר שֶׁנִּתְחַדֵּשׁ בָּהּ.

אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: זְנוּתָא בְּבֵיתָא כִּי קַרְיָא לְשׁוּמְשְׁמָא. וְאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: תּוּקְפָּא בְּבֵיתָא כִּי קַרְיָא לְשׁוּמְשְׁמָא. אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי בְּאִיתְּתָא, אֲבָל בְּגַבְרָא לֵית לַן בַּהּ.

וְאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: בַּתְּחִילָּה, קוֹדֶם שֶׁחָטְאוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל, הָיְתָה שְׁכִינָה שׁוֹרָה עִם כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ מִתְהַלֵּךְ בְּקֶרֶב מַחֲנֶךָ״. כֵּיוָן שֶׁחָטְאוּ נִסְתַּלְּקָה שְׁכִינָה מֵהֶם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְלֹא יִרְאֶה בְךָ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר וְשָׁב מֵאַחֲרֶיךָ״.

אָמַר רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן: כׇּל הָעוֹשֶׂה מִצְוָה אַחַת בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה — מְקַדַּמְתּוֹ וְהוֹלֶכֶת לְפָנָיו לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהָלַךְ לְפָנֶיךָ צִדְקֶךָ״. וְכׇל הָעוֹבֵר עֲבֵירָה אַחַת בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה — מְלַפַּפְתּוֹ וְהוֹלֶכֶת לְפָנָיו לְיוֹם הַדִּין, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״יִלָּפְתוּ אׇרְחוֹת דַּרְכָּם יַעֲלוּ בַתֹּהוּ וְיֹאבֵדוּ״.

רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר: קְשׁוּרָה בּוֹ כְּכֶלֶב, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְלֹא שָׁמַע אֵלֶיהָ לִשְׁכַּב אֶצְלָהּ לִהְיוֹת עִמָּהּ״. ״לִשְׁכַּב אֶצְלָהּ״ — בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה, ״לִהְיוֹת עִמָּהּ״ — לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא.
תְּנַן הָתָם, שֶׁהָיָה בַּדִּין:

וּמָה עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה, שֶׁאֵין אוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינָהּ מִתְקַיֶּימֶת בְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁנַיִם, עֵדוּת הָאַחֲרוֹנָה, שֶׁאוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁלֹּא תִּתְקַיֵּים בְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁנַיִם?
תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְעֵד אֵין בָּהּ״, כֹּל שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהּ.

וְקַל וָחוֹמֶר לְעֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה מֵעַתָּה: וּמָה עֵדוּת הָאַחֲרוֹנָה, שֶׁאוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — מִתְקַיֶּימֶת בְּעֵד אֶחָד, עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה, שֶׁאֵין אוֹסַרְתָּהּ אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁתִּתְקַיֵּים בְּעֵד אֶחָד?

תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״כִּי מָצָא בָהּ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר״, וּלְהַלָּן הוּא אוֹמֵר ״עַל פִּי שְׁנֵי עֵדִים אוֹ עַל פִּי שְׁלֹשָׁה עֵדִים יָקוּם דָּבָר״. מָה ״דָּבָר״ הָאָמוּר לְהַלָּן — עַל פִּי שְׁנַיִם עֵדִים, אַף כָּאן — עַל פִּי שְׁנַיִם.
הַאי מִ״כִּי מָצָא בָהּ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר״ נָפְקָא? מִ״בָּהּ״ נָפְקָא: בָּהּ — וְלֹא בְּקִינּוּי, בָּהּ — וְלֹא בִּסְתִירָה מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ!
הָכִי נָמֵי קָאָמַר: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״בָּהּ״: בָּהּ — וְלֹא בְּקִינּוּי, בָּהּ — וְלֹא בִּסְתִירָה.

וְטוּמְאָה בְּעָלְמָא בְּלֹא קִינּוּי וּבְלֹא סְתִירָה, דְּלָא מְהֵימַן עֵד אֶחָד, מְנָלַן? נֶאֱמַר כָּאן: ״כִּי מָצָא בָהּ עֶרְוַת דָּבָר״, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן: ״עַל פִּי שְׁנֵי עֵדִים אוֹ עַל פִּי שְׁלֹשָׁה עֵדִים יָקוּם דָּבָר״. מָה ״דָּבָר״ הָאָמוּר לְהַלָּן — עֵדִים שְׁנַיִם, אַף כָּאן — עֵדִים שְׁנַיִם.
תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵי זוֹ הִיא עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה — זוֹ עֵדוּת סְתִירָה, עֵדוּת אַחֲרוֹנָה — זוֹ עֵדוּת טוּמְאָה.
human_translation: And Rabbi Akiva If so, let the Merciful One write: for her,” and be silent. Why do I “May he become impure”? Learn from

And Rabbi Yishmael Since wrote: “For her,” also wrote: “May he become impure,” for as was taught by the school of Rabbi Yishmael. As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Every passage that was stated and repeated, was repeated only for the novel element introduced therein.
“Of them may you take your bondmen forever” optional; the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: mandatory,

What is the reason of Rabbi Yishmael? Since it is written “You shall save alive nothing that breathes” it was necessary to write: “Of them may you take your bondmen forever” as well, to permit one from any of the nations who engaged in sexual intercourse with a Canaanite woman and she bore him a child. that you are permitted to purchase

as it is taught From where that one from the nations who engaged in sexual intercourse with a Canaanite woman, and she bore him a child, that you are permitted to purchase as a slave? The verse states: “Moreover, of the children of the strangers that do sojourn among you, of them may you buy”

might even a Canaanite who engaged in sexual intercourse with a woman from the nations and she bore him a child, that you are permitted to purchase as a slave, the verse states: “Which they have given birth to in your land,” from the born in your land but not from the reside in your land,
And Rabbi Akiva derives from “Of them may you buy.” why do I “Of them may you take your bondmen forever” to mandatory
And Rabbi Yishmael “of them,” but not of your brethren,
And Rabbi Akiva your brethren is derived from the latter of the verse, “But over your brethren the children of Israel you shall not rule, one over another, with rigor”

And Rabbi Yishmael since it is written: “But over your brethren,” it also writes “of them,” because of that was taught by the school of Rabbi Yishmael. As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Every passage that was stated and repeated, was repeated only for the novel element introduced therein.

Rav Ḥisda says: Licentious in a home like a worm [ karya ] to sesame [ shumeshema ]. And Rav Ḥisda says: Anger in a home like a worm to sesame. this and that, with regard to the woman but with regard to the man, we do not have with regard to it,

And Rav Ḥisda says: Initially, before the Jewish people sinned, the Divine Presence resided with each and every one as it is stated: “For the Lord your God walks in the midst of your camp” Once they sinned, the Divine Presence withdrew from them, as it is stated “That He see no unseemly matter in you, and turn away from you”

Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says Rabbi Yonatan says: Anyone who fulfills one mitzva in this world, precedes him and goes before him to the World-to-Come, as it is stated: “And your righteousness shall go before you, And anyone who commits one transgression in this world, it shrouds him and goes before him to the Day of Judgment, as it is stated: “The paths of their way do wind, they go up into the waste, and are lost”
Rabbi Elazar says: is chained to him like a dog, as it is stated “That he listened not to her, to lie by her, or to be with her” “to lie by her” in this world, “to be with her” to the World-to-Come.
We learned elsewhere as, by right, should have been

And just as the first testimony which does not forbid her an irrevocable prohibition, is not established with fewer than two the final testimony which forbids her an irrevocable prohibition, is it not logical that it not be established with fewer than two
the verse states: “And there is no witness against her” any that there is against her

And now an a fortiori with regard to the first testimony And just as the final testimony which forbids her an irrevocable prohibition, is established with one witness, the first testimony, which does not forbid her an irrevocable prohibition, is it not logical that it should be established with one witness?

the verse states: because he has found some unseemly matter [ davar ] about her” and there, it states: “By the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses shall a matter [ davar ] be established” just as “matter” stated there by the mouth of two witnesses, so too here, by the mouth of two

this derived from: “Because he has found some unseemly matter about her” It is derived from: against her [ bah ]” With regard to it, but not with regard to warning. With regard to it, but not with regard to seclusion. should have
That is also what he is saying. The verse states: against her [ bah ],” With regard to it [ bah ], but not with regard to warning. With regard to it, but not with regard to seclusion.

And defilement in general, without warning and without seclusion, from where do we that one witness is not deemed credible? Here it is stated: “Because he has found some unseemly matter about her” and there it is stated: “By the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses shall a matter be established” just as “matter” stated there two witnesses, so too here, two witnesses.
The Sages taught which is the first testimony? This testimony of seclusion. the final testimony? This testimony of defilement.
llm_translation: And Rabbi Akiva — if so, let the Merciful One write “to her” and be silent; “he shall become impure” — for what do I need it? Learn from it.

And Rabbi Yishmaʿel, since it is written “lah,” it wrote also “yitamma.” According to that which is taught in the house of Rabbi Yishmaʿel. For it was taught in the house of Rabbi Yishmaʿel: Any parashah that was said and was repeated, it was not repeated except for the sake of a matter that was renewed in it.
“‘Le-olam bahem ta‘avodu’ — permission, the words of Rabbi Yishma‘el. Rabbi ‘Akiva says: obligation.”

What is the reason of Rabbi Yishma’el? — Since it is written: “You shall not let live any soul,” it was necessary also to write: “Forever in them you shall serve,” to permit one from all the nations who came upon the Kena’anit and begot from her a son, that you are permitted to acquire him.

As it is taught: From where is it derived with regard to one of the ummot who came upon the Kena’anit and begot from her a son, that you are permitted to acquire him as an eved? The verse teaches to say: “And also from the children of the toshavim who sojourn with you, from them you shall acquire.”

Talmudic text: Could it be, even the Kena‘ani who came upon one of the ummot and begot from her a son, that you are permitted to acquire him as an ‘eved? The Talmud says: “whom they begot in your land”; from those born in your land, and not from the gerim in your land.
And Rabbi ʿAkiva—from “from them you shall acquire” it emerges; “forever with them you shall work” why do I need it?—for obligation.
And Rabbi Yishmaʿel: “bahem” — and not with your brothers.

And Rabbi Akiva: “with your brothers” — from the latter clause of the verse it emerges: “And with your brothers, the children of Yisrael, a man with his brother you shall not rule over him with harsh labor.”

וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: And Rabbi Yishmaʿel: אַיְּידֵי דִּכְתִיב ״וּבְאַחֵיכֶם״, Since it is written “and with your brothers,” כְּתִיב נָמֵי ״בָּהֶם״. it is written also “in them.” לְכִדְתָנֵי דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל. according to that which was taught of the house of Rabbi Yishmaʿel. דְּתָנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: For it was taught of the house of Rabbi Yishmaʿel: כָּל פָּרָשָׁה שֶׁנֶּאֶמְרָה וְנִישְׁנֵית, Any parashah that was said and was repeated, לֹא נִישְׁנֵית אֶלָּא בִּשְׁבִיל דָּבָר שֶׁנִּתְחַדֵּשׁ בָּהּ. was not repeated except on account of a matter that was renewed in it.

אָמַר Rav Ḥisda: Z’nuta in the house is like a worm to sesame. וְאָמַר Rav Ḥisda: Tukpa in the house is like a worm to sesame. אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי—both this and that—are in a woman, but in a man we have not in it.

And Rav Ḥisda said: At the beginning, before Israel sinned, the Shekhina was dwelling with each and every one, as it is said: “For the LORD your God walks in the midst of your camp.” Once they sinned, the Shekhina withdrew from them, as it is said: “And He shall not see in you the nakedness of a thing, and turn back from behind you.”

אָמַר רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן: Rabbi Shemu’el bar Naḥmani said, Rabbi Yonatan said: כׇּל הָעוֹשֶׂה מִצְוָה אַחַת בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה — anyone who does one mitzvah in this world — מְקַדַּמְתּוֹ וְהוֹלֶכֶת לְפָנָיו לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא, it precedes him and goes before him to the World-to-Come, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: as it is said: ״וְהָלַךְ לְפָנֶיךָ צִדְקֶךָ״ “and your righteousness shall go before you.” וְכׇל הָעוֹבֵר עֲבֵירָה אַחַת בָּעוֹלָם הַזֶּה — and anyone who transgresses one transgression in this world — מְלַפַּפְתּוֹ וְהוֹלֶכֶת לְפָנָיו לְיוֹם הַדִּין, it wraps him and goes before him to the Day of Judgment, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: as it is said: ״יִלָּפְתוּ אׇרְחוֹת דַּרְכָּם יַעֲלוּ בַתֹּהוּ וְיֹאבֵדוּ״ “the paths of their way are wrapped; they go up into chaos and are lost.”

Rabbi Elazar says: Bound to him like a dog, as it is said: “And he did not listen to her, to lie beside her, to be with her.” “To lie beside her” — in this world; “to be with her” — for the World-to-Come.
We learned there, that it was in the law:

And what of the first testimony, that its prohibition is not a prohibition forever — it does not stand with fewer than two; the latter testimony, that its prohibition is a prohibition forever — is it not דין that it should not stand with fewer than two?
Talmud to say: “and a witness there is not in her,” all that there is in her.

And an a fortiori to the first testimony from now: And just as the later testimony, that you forbid her a prohibition of forever — is upheld with one witness, the first testimony, that you do not forbid her a prohibition of forever — is it not law that it be upheld with one witness?

Talmud to say: “for he has found in her *ervat davar*,” and there, he says: “by the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses a matter shall stand.” Just as “matter” said there — by the mouth of two witnesses, so too here — by the mouth of two.
This “from: ‘because he has found in her ʿervat davar’ ”—does it go out? From “in her” it goes out: “in her”—and not with kinui, “in her”—and not with setirah—he needs it!
So too he is saying: *Talmud* to say “**bah**”: **bah** — and not with a *kinnuy*, **bah** — and not in concealment.

And impurity in general, without kinui and without setirah, that one witness is not believed— from where do we derive it? It is said here: “for he has found in her a matter of nakedness,” and it is said there: “by the mouth of two witnesses or by the mouth of three witnesses shall a matter be established.” Just as “matter” said there— two witnesses, so too here— two witnesses.

תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: The Rabbis taught: אֵי זוֹ הִיא עֵדוּת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה — Which is the first testimony? — זוֹ עֵדוּת סְתִירָה, This is testimony of seclusion; עֵדוּת אַחֲרוֹנָה — The later testimony — זוֹ עֵדוּת טוּמְאָה. This is testimony of tum’ah.

sentences.text: וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא — אִם כֵּן, לִיכְתּוֹב רַחֲמָנָא ״לָהּ״ וְלִישְׁתּוֹק, ״יִטַּמָּא״ לְמָה לִי? שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
